courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Biochemistry of Health and Disease
courses.description: This course provides a general introduction to the biochemistry of health and disease. Topics covered include nutrition and health, biomolecules and energy metabolism, molecular genetics and its applications in modern medicine, the immune system in health and disease, and the biochemistry of cancer. It is suitable for students (other than those who major in Life Sciences) who want to learn about the biochemical basis of various cellular functions and their relevance to disease. This course provides the fundamental knowledge that is essential to the study of other biochemistry or life science courses.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken LSCI1002.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:

1. describe the nutrients derived from diet and their functions.

2. explain the basic features, functions, and clinical relevance of enzymes.

3. discuss how energy is produced from metabolism of nutrients and the clinical significances.

4. explain how genetic information is encoded and executed in cells, and applications of recombinant technology.

5. discuss how the immune system protects us from pathogens, and the clinical manoeuvres of the immune system.

6. describe the cause and treatment strategy of cancer.

完成課程以後，學生應該掌握以下重點：
1. 膳食中的營養成份以及其功效

2. 酶的基本特性，功效和臨床上的應用

3. 能量是如何由營養成份代謝而產生及其在臨床應用上的重要性

4. 在細胞中遺傳信息如何得以編碼和解碼，以及重組技術的實際應用

5. 免疫系統是如何保衛我們遠離病原體的侵害，以及臨床上的免疫調控

6. 腫瘤的起因和治療方法

完成课程以后，学生应该掌握以下重点：
1. 膳食中的营养成份以及其功效

2. 酶的基本特性，功效和临床上的应用

3. 能量是如何由营养成份代谢而产生及其在临床应用上的重要性

4. 在细胞中遗传信息如何得以编码和译码，以及重组技术的实际应用

5. 免疫系统是如何保卫我们远离病原体的侵害，以及临床上的免疫调控

6. 肿瘤的起因和治疗方法

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Basic Concepts in Biological Sciences

meetings.instructor: Dr. CHIU Chi Ming Lawrence
Dr. CHIU Chi Ming Lawrence

courses.description: This foundation course is designed for students who have not taken science courses with a biology component at the senior secondary school level. It presents our current understandings on cells and molecules of life, genetics and evolution, organisms and environment, and health and diseases. Those students who have successfully completed this course will have a solid foundation for studying more advanced courses in life sciences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken LSCI1002 or 1003.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To describe and integrate some basic knowledge in life sciences

2. To apply the knowledge in daily-life scenarios, e.g. distinguishing facts and fallacies of some life-science topics that appear on mass media

3. To develop generic skills necessary in life sciences, e.g. using scientific method to understand and solve problems

修畢此課程後，學生應能︰
1. 掌握及整合基本的生命科學知識

2. 應用知識於日常生活中，分析於媒體中與生命科學有關的資訊及判斷其真確性

3. 具備生命科學研究的共通能力，利用科學方法去理解及解決疑難

修毕此课程后，学生应能︰
1. 掌握及整合基本的生命科学知识

2. 应用知识于日常生活中，分析于媒体中与生命科学有关的信息及判断其真确性

3. 具备生命科学研究的共通能力，利用科学方法去理解及解决疑难
courses.course_syllabus:
A. Cells and Molecules of Life

1. Molecules of life

- The significance of water, inorganic ions, carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and nucleic acids to life

2. Cellular organization

- The Fluid Mosaic Model to explain the properties and functions of cell membrane

- Sub-cellular organization of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells

- Cellular organization of animal and plant cells

3. Cell cycle and division

- Importance of cell division in growth and reproduction

- The processes of mitosis and meiosis

4. Cellular energetics

- The properties of enzyme and its roles in metabolism

- The major steps of photochemical reactions and carbon fixation in photosynthesis

- The major steps of glycolysis, aerobic and anaerobic pathways in respiration

B. Genetics and Evolution

1. Basic genetics

- Mendel’s laws of inheritance

2. Molecular genetics

- Structural and functional relationships of nucleic acids, genes and chromosomes

- The process of protein synthesis

- Applications of recombinant DNA technology and DNA fingerprinting

- Human Genome Project and its implications

3. Biodiversity and evolution

- “Six Kingdoms and Three Domains” classification approaches proposed by Carl Woese

- Origins of life

- Mechanism of evolution

C. Organisms and Environment

1. Essential life processes in plants

- Plants as autotrophs

- Absorption of water and minerals

- Gas exchange

- Transpiration

2. Essential life processes in humans

- Humans as heterotrophs

- Ingestion, digestion, absorption, assimilation and egestion of food substances

- Gas exchange

- Circulatory system and lymphatic system

3. Reproduction, growth and development

- Asexual reproduction

- Sexual reproduction in flowering plants

- Sexual reproduction in humans

- Stages of growth in annual plants and humans

4. Coordination and response in humans

- Central nervous system

- General plan of the endocrine system

- Different components of the musculo-skeletal system

5. Ecosystems

- Abiotic and biotic components of an ecosystem

- Flow of energy and cycling of materials in an ecosystem

- Conservation of ecosystems

D. Health and Diseases

1. Personal health

- Significance of healthy lifestyles

2. Diseases

- The concept of disease

- How infectious diseases are transmitted

- The causal relationships between the incidence of various non-infectious diseases and certain lifestyles

- Prevention of diseases

3. Body defense mechanisms

- Non-specific defense mechanisms

- Specific defense mechanisms

courses.description: This course aims to bring the students a holistic understanding of how life works. Basic concepts of biochemistry, cell biology, genetics and physiology are taught in the context of how life evolving from unicellular to multicellular organisms.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to describe, integrate, and apply basic concepts of biological sciences, including fundamentals of biochemistry, cell biology, genetics and physiology.
2. Students will possess the fundamental knowledge that facilitates their learning in higher level courses of major programmes in life sciences.
3. Students will develop generic skills necessary in life sciences, including acquisition of appropriate study techniques, ability to ask critical questions, and application of problem-solving skills.
4. Students, through what they have learnt, will be able to develop popular science educational materials for their peers and high-school students.

1. 學生將能夠描述、整合、並應用生物科學的基本概念，包括基本生物化學、細胞生物學、遺傳學、和生理學。
2. 學生將具備生命科學的基本知識，有利於他們學習更進階的有關的課程。
3. 學生將發展在生命科學領域所必需的能力，包括適當的學習技巧、判性思維和解決問題的能力。
4. 學生將能通過學到的知識，為同輩及高中學生開發科普教材。
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Topics:

* Membrane and Compartmentation
* Energy, Life and Metabolism
* The Central Dogma
* How life evolves from prokaryotes to eukaryotes, from unicellular to multicellular organisms
* Cell Division
* Differentiation and Development
* Cell Communications
* Reproduction

課程主題:

* 細胞膜與隔室
* 能量、生命與新陳代謝
* 分子生物學的中心法則
* 生命如何從原核生物進化到真核生物、從單細胞生物到多細胞生物
* 細胞分裂
* 分化與發育
* 細胞通訊
* 生殖

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Life Sciences for Engineers
courses.description: This course gives engineering students exposure to some of the basic and essential concepts in biology and biotechnology. Topics include cell structure and energy metabolism, DNA structure and replication, protein structure and function, genetic engineering, stem cell and tissue regeneration, neural biology, cardiovascular system, muscle and skeletal system of animals, microbes and microbial biotechnology. The overall aim of this course is to introduce students with the fundamental ideas and concepts in life sciences especially those with relevance to engineering studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken LSCI1001.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to understand and integrate some basic concepts of biology and biotechnology, especially those relevant to engineering studies

2. Students will develop generic skills necessary in life sciences, including acquisition of appropriate study techniques, ability to ask critical questions, and application of problem-solving skills

1. 學生將能夠理解和整合一些與工程研究相關的生物學和生物技術基本概念。

2. 學生將培養出在生命科學領域中所必需的共通能力，包括適當的學習技巧，提出關鍵問題 和解決問題的能力。

1. 学生将能够理解和整合一些与工程研究相关的生物学和生物技术基本概念。

2. 学生将培养出在生命科学领域中所必需的共通能力，包括适当的学习技巧，提出关键问题 和解决问题的能力。
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.description: This course covers basic concepts in biodiversity and different life forms. Students will be introduced to organisms on terrestrial (soil, grassland, freshwater), in ocean (pelagic, coral reef, intertidal, deep-sea), as well as their history on earth. Concepts in evolution (microevolution, speciation, macroevolution), ecology (population ecology, community, and ecosystems), and genetics related to biodiversity and different life forms will also be introduced.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge: Organisms on terrestrial (soil, grassland, freshwater), in ocean (pelagic, coral reef, intertidal, deep-sea), as well as their history on earth. Concepts in evolution (microevolution, speciation, macroevolution), ecology (population ecology, community, and ecosystems), and genetics related to biodiversity and different life forms will also be introduced.

Skill: Acquisition of appropriate study techniques, ability to ask critical questions, and application of problem-solving skills through examinations

Value: Appreciation of biodiversity and different life forms, sense of biological conservation and other environmental issues, awareness on the latest developments and advancements in biology.
courses.course_syllabus:
* History of Life (An oxygen atmosphere, From prokaryotic to eukaryotic organism, From a single cell to multicellular organism, The Move to Land: stories from plants and vertebrates, Dinosaur world and the day after, History of Human)
* Pelagic Life - Phytoplankton, zooplankton
* Coral Reef Life - Corals and coral communities, Fish and other nekton
* Intertidal Life - Rocky shores and Kelp forests, Mudflats and Mangroves
* Deep-Sea Life - Deep sea communities
* Soil Life (Soil ecosystem and animals, soil and plant interaction, Soil and Climate change)
* Terrestrial Life (Succession and climax, vegetation covers, Animals and seed dispersal)
* Grassland Life (Types of grassland, Savanna and Great migration)
* Freshwater Life (Stream communities, Land-water interaction)
* Darwin and Evolution, Evolution of Populations
* Origin of Species, History of Life
* Population Ecology, Community Ecology, Ecosystems
* Genetics and Life

meetings.instructor:
Professor CHAN Michael Kenneth, 
Professor CHEN Sijie

courses.description: For life sciences majors to appreciate public interest, and ethical concerns from the society, to develop their professional mind. Students will need to consider controversial issues relating to reproduction and life, cloning, stem cell research, animal testing, uses and testing of drug, scientific research practices, clinical trials, intellectual and property rights, etc. Related ordinances and regulations will also be introduced and examined in this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: LSCI1002.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The course provides guidance to the students for developing a professional and creative mindset with considerations from the general public and the society. Students taken this course are anticipated to understand the problems associated the following controversial issues: meaning of life and reproduction technology, embryonic stem cell and cloning research, animal uses and testing, drug uses and testing, clinical trials and scientific research, intellectual and property rights, etc. The students are expected to learn and understand existing laws and regulations related to bioethics and scientific conducts.

本科為同學發展其專業及創意思維的同時，得兼顧公眾及社會的考慮。同學完成本科後得明白以下項目所引起的具爭議問題：生殖技術和生命的意義，胚胎幹細胞和克隆的硏究，動物的使用和測試，藥物的使用和測試，臨牀試驗及科學硏究，和尊重知識產權。同學應學習及明白現有生物道德和科學倫理的相關法律和規章。

本科为同学发展其专业及创意思维的同时，得兼顾公众及社会的考虑。同学完成本科后得明白以下项目所引起的具争议问题：生殖技术和生命的意义，胚胎干细胞和克隆的硏究，动物的使用和测试，药物的使用和测试，临牀试验及科学硏究，和尊重知识产权。同学应学习及明白现有生物道德和科学伦理的相关法律和规章。
courses.course_syllabus:
The following topics with their associated ethical concerns and laws, will be introduced.

[1] Reproduction technology

[2] Euthanasia and the meaning of life

[3] Cloning and manipulation of embryonic stem cells

[4] Animal testing and handling

[5] Clinical trial conducts

[6] Drug abuse, testing, overdose of antibiotics and drug resistance

[7] Scientific conducts: how to design relevant controls in your experiments to collect reliable data for hypothesis testing?

[8] Intellectual properties: how to make claims of your invention and respect others’ claims?

以下項目,及其相關倫理考慮及法例，會被論及：

[1] 生殖技術

[2] 安樂死及生命的意義

[3] 克隆及胚胎幹細胞的操控

[4] 動物的測試和使用

[5] 臨牀測試的倫理問題

[7] 科學倫理 : 如何設計對照組實驗以收集可靠數據來驗証假說?

[8] 知識產權 : 如何為你的發明申請專利及尊重別人的專利?

以下项目，及其相关伦理考虑及法例，会被论及：
[1] 生殖技术

[2] 安乐死及生命的意义

[3] 克隆及胚胎干细胞的操控

[4] 动物的测试和使用

[5] 临牀测试的伦理问题

[6] 药物滥用，测试，过量使用抗生素和抗药性

[7] 科学伦理 : 如何设计对照组实验以收集可靠数据来验证假说?

[8] 知识产权 : 如何为你的发明申请专利及尊重别人的专利?

After studying this course, students are expected to experience the following learning outcomes

associated with global citizenship and social enterprisingness:

1. Learn how to develop and design a project to engage the community and apply knowledge learned to solve societal problems or issues in locality around us

2. Learn how to engage people and build up your team to work together

3. Learn how to allocate tasks on a specific project and set deadline to finish on time the jobs proposed

4. Learn how to explain your ideas to engage the community and your peers with innovative media

5. Learn how to acquire and collect data or information, and how to analyze and compare your data or information to organize the results and discussions

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Structural Biology
courses.description: This course provides a detailed overview of two principles structural biology methods used for the study of the structure-function relationship biomolecules: cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and X-ray crystallography. Cryo-EM, a powerful technique involving rapid cooling of biological specimens in vitreous ice to preserve the structure for EM analysis, has become a dominant technique in the field of structural biology. Its board applications range from high-resolution structure determination of protein complexes using single particle analysis to visualization of subcellular structures in their native environment using tomography. On the other hand, X-ray crystallography is a powerful tool in studying small proteins and protein-drug interactions. Today, cryo-EM and X-ray crystallography are indispensable and irreplaceable tools in research to reveal unprecedented architectural details of macromolecular assemblies that are invaluable to our mechanistic understanding of the biological world as well as drug discovery. This course will cover the fundamental principles and concepts with an emphasis on practical aspects of these two fundamental techniques. Basic techniques, such as specimen preparation, machine operation, data acquisition, computational image analysis and structure solving, 3D map interpretation, and model building will be covered. With an emphasis on high-resolution structure determination, this course provides the necessary hands-on experience and entry-level trainings for students to perform cryo-EM and X-ray crystallography in their future research projects.
courses.course_syllabus:
Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM): Cryo-EM is a state-of-the-art technique for determining high-resolution structures of macromolecular complexes. Its basic principles and practical procedure will be covered.

X-ray Crystallography: X-ray crystallography is a common method for structural elucidation of smaller proteins and protein-small molecule interactions. Its basic principles and practical procedure will be covered.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Introductory Live-Cell Imaging: Applications and Analyses
courses.description: Most structural and functional cellular changes can only be visualized in living cells, tissues or even intact animals. Modern fluorescent live-cell imaging techniques is therefore crucial for scientists to study such dynamic changes at the cellular and even molecular level. This undergraduate course provides entry level live-cell imaging microscopy trainings and intact specimens/animals preparations in a laboratory setting, while covering the fundamental principles via lectures. Students will have the precious opportunities to obtain hands-on experience with some of the most advanced high speed/super-resolution microscopes in the field, such as spinning disc, Two-photon and STED laser confocal microscopes. Data processing/analysis using advanced image software, such as IMARIS, will also be covered. Upon completion of the course, students will be able to incorporate these powerful microscopy and image processing/analysis techniques into their future research to study cellular dynamics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

1) Explain the principles and concepts of fluorescent live-cell imaging, and apply them in practical experiments in the laboratory.

2) Acquire hands-on experience in live-cell / intact animal imaging using some of the most advanced confocal microscopy techniques in the field.

3) Apply live-cell microscopy in their future research to address major questions in biology.

完成課程後, 學生將會能夠：

1. 解釋熒光活細胞成像的原理和概念，並將其應用於實驗中
2. 獲得使用一些最先進的共聚焦顯微鏡技術來進行活細胞/完整動物成像實驗的實作經驗
3. 在未來的研究中應用活細胞顯微術來解決生物學中的重要的問題
courses.course_syllabus:
This course aims to equip students with necessary knowledge and skills to perform fluorescent live-cell imaging in their future research. The course will cover time-lapse imaging of fluorescent proteins in mammalian cell culture, live-imaging of dissected, semi-living *Drosophila* larval neuromuscular junction and brain.

本科旨在讓學生掌握在未來研究中進行熒光活細胞成像所需的知識和技能。本科將涵蓋哺乳動物細胞培養中熒光蛋白的實時成像、解剖、半活的果蠅幼蟲神經肌肉接頭和大腦的實時成像。

courses.description: The first part of this course introduces the sources, chemical nature and environmental effects of major environmental toxicants. The second part covers the fundamental basis of toxic action of chemical substances including environmental toxicants on living systems. The third part provides students an understanding of the basic principles and biochemical mechanisms of toxicology. This course will also cover the basic concepts of biomonitoring and ecotoxicology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC3520. Pre-requisite: BCHE2030 and BIOL2120.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will understand the sources and chemical nature of selected toxicants, and the carcinogenesis, hepatotoxicity and neurotoxicity caused by the toxicants. They will know how the toxicity of chemical substances including some common toxic metals, carcinogens, pesticides and natural toxins can be changed. They will also study the basic techniques in ecotoxicology, and able to plan and carry out environmental monitoring and ecotoxicological studies of the impacts of environmental pollutants on local organisms.

學生能夠瞭解到一般毒物包括金屬、致癌物、農藥和天然毒物的來源和其所引致的癌病，肝和神經系统中毒的原因，及導致生物中 毒的因素。學生應學習生態毒理學的基本技術，並能夠計劃和進行環境監測，及針對環境污染物對本地生物的影響，進行生態毒理學研究。

学生能够了解到一般毒物包括金属、致癌物、农药和天然毒物的来源和其所引致的癌病，肝和神经系统中毒的原 因，及导致生物中 毒的因素。学生应学习生态毒理学的基本技术，并能够计划和进行环境监测，及针对环境污染物 对本地生物的影响，进行生态毒理学研究。
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Sources and chemical nature of environmental toxicants
2. Environmental effects on the selected toxicants
3. Microbial bioassay and genotoxicity study
4. Biomonitoring, bioindicators and biomarkers
5. Ecological effects of the toxicants (Eco-toxicology)
6. Regulatory toxicology and risk assessment
7. Biochemical aspects of toxicology and dose-response relationship
8. Biological factors that influence toxicity (in vitro/ in vivo analyses, toxicant processing)
9. Chemical factors that influence toxicity (classes of toxicants)
10. Chemical carcinogenesis, mutagenesis and cellular sites of toxic actions
11. Hepatotoxicity and drug metabolisms (Phase I, II and III metabolism)
12. Reproductive and developmental toxicity (teratogenesis)
13. Neurotoxicity and natural toxins

1. 環境毒物的來源和化學性質
2. 所選毒物對環境的影響
3. 微生物生物測定和遺傳毒性研究
4. 生物監測，生物指示劑和生物標記物
5. 有毒物質的生態影響（生態毒理學）
6. 監管毒理學和風險評估
7. 毒理學的生化方面和劑量反應關係
8. 影響毒性的生物因素（體外/體內分析，毒物處理）
9. 影響毒性的化學因素（毒物類別）
10. 化學致癌作用，誘變和毒性作用引起的細胞改變部位
11. 肝毒性和藥物代謝（I期，II期和III期代謝）
12. 生殖和發育毒性（致畸作用）
13. 神經毒性和天然毒素

1. 环境毒物的来源和化学性质
2. 所选毒物对环境的影响
3. 微生物生物测定和遗传毒性研究
4. 生物监测，生物指示剂和生物标记物
5. 有毒物质的生态影响（生态毒理学）
6. 监管毒理学和风险评估
7. 毒理学的生化方面和剂量反应关系
8. 影响毒性的生物因素（体外/体内分析，毒物处理）
9. 影响毒性的化学因素（毒物类别）
10. 化学致癌作用，诱变和毒性作用引起的细胞改变部位
11. 肝毒性和药物代谢（I期，II期和III期代谢）
12. 生殖和发育毒性（致畸作用）
13. 神经毒性和天然毒素

courses.description: Students, with the help of a supervisor, will identify a specific topic in life sciences to perform a literature research, and critically assess the scientific basis of the conclusions drawn. Students will discuss regularly with the supervisor and summarize the research findings in an oral presentation and a review paper.Advisory: This capstone course is for final year students major in Biochemistry, Biology, Environmental Science, Food and Nutritional Sciences, and Molecular Biotechnology. For other students who want to enroll to this course, they have to first seek consent from the course coordinator.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The students will be able to:

1. find relevant scientific literature in life sciences

2. interpret and analyze the experimental data presented in the scientific literature

3. understand the research methodology

4. summarize the findings in the scientific literature, and present them to the

peers

5. write a review article on a current research topic in life sciences

學生將會發展以下能力:

1. 搜尋與生命科學相關文獻的技巧

2. 具批判性思維閱讀及分析解釋有關文獻的實驗數據

3. 認知及思考其研究方法

4. 概述相關文獻的結果，並向導師及同學匯報

5. 撰寫現今生物科學的發展及關注問題之報告

学生将会发展以下能力:

1. 搜寻与生命科学相关文献的技巧

2. 具批判性思维阅读及分析解释有关文献的实验数据

3. 认知及思考其研究方法

4. 概述相关文献的结果，并向导师及同学汇报

5. 撰写现今生物科学的发展及关注问题之报告
courses.course_syllabus:
Students, with the help of a supervisor, will identify a specific research topic in life sciences to perform a literature research. The students will first search for the relevant scientific literatures using online databases such as PubMed (www.pubmed.org). The scientific literatures should cover both review articles as well as original research papers. The students should understand the methodology of research described so that they can critically assess the experimental basis of the conclusions drawn in these papers. After reading a number of relevant papers in the selected topics, the students will summarize the research findings and present them in an oral presentation and submit a review article.

同學將經由導師的指導及協助下，對與生命科學相關之研究課題進行文獻研究。同學需利用相關的數據庫如PubMed (www.pubmed.org）對有關的科學文獻,猶是其原創性研究論文, 及其涵蓋的評論文章與資科進行搜索及研究。同學亦需深入理解及應用相關的實驗依據及其方法. 並就其文獻調查提交報告及作口頭專題報告。

同学将经由导师的指导及协助下，对与生命科学相关之研究课题进行文献研究。同学需利用相关的数据库如PubMed (www.pubmed.org）对有关的科学文献,犹是其原创性研究论文, 及其涵盖的评论文章与资科进行搜索及研究。同学亦需深入理解及应用相关的实验依据及其方法. 并就其文献调查提交报告及作口头专题报告。

1) Direct feedback from students to teachers

2) An open discussion session after the oral presentations of the students in the term end

1) 學生跟導師直接反映

2) 口頭報告後的討論環節

1) 学生跟导师直接反映

2) 口头报告后的讨论环节

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Group Research in Life Sciences
courses.description: This course is a capstone course consists of group projects to investigate the heated topics related to Life Sciences, such that students will be inspired by how different fields of life sciences have made their impacts on the globalized knowledge-based society of Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BCHE4902, BIOL4902, CMBI4902, ENSC4902, FNSC4902, MBTE4902 or LSCI4000.
courses.course_syllabus:
The students should take the initiative to form groups with three to four students at the beginning of the term. Students from different programmes are highly recommended. Students in one group should discuss with their supervisors and compromise a topic for the group research project. This project should not be just a purely academic research study but a project related to various impact of life sciences on the society of Hong Kong with or without some laboratory-based research components. The students in a group are required to investigate the proposed topic with teamwork and team building elements. The students should first survey the background of their research project and identify the scientific questions they want to address. The students then design and perform the laboratory-based experiments and/or non-laboratory-based research for this project under the guidance of the supervisors and submit a research proposal in the term end.

Potential projects should include components as follows,
1. Knowledge-oriented training
Students should attend laboratory training, workshop or tutorials, in which the core knowledge of relevant scientific knowledge of life sciences, including laboratory-based experimental design, scientific paper reading and writing, and basic calculation and statistics in life sciences, etc. are given.

2. Technical skill-orientated training
Students should arrange their practical training, including laboratory-based research skills, information technology and data search, computer software for data analysis, etc. for their projects.

3. Experience and exposure enhancement
Students should participate in various learning activities such as 1) laboratory-based research; 2) surveys; 3) site visits; 4) field studies, etc. and learn to appreciate the applications of Life Sciences for social enterprises.

4. Teamwork and team building
Students should learn the importance of good collaboration among the people working in a group to achieve a shared goal. The team members should share the vision to complete the project effectively and efficiently before a deadline. Also, students working in a team should learn to trust and respect each other and every member should have its own duties and responsibilities.

在學期開始時，學生應主動與三至四個學生組成小組。小組建議由來自不同課程的學生組成。同組學生應該與他們的導師討論，並為小組研究項目確定一個主題。這個項目不應只是純粹的學術研究，而應與生命科學對香港社會的各種影響有關，當中可以帶有或不帶有實驗室研究的成分。小組中的學生需要通過團隊合作和帶有團隊建設的元素來研究提議的主題。學生應首先調查研究項目的背景並確定他們要解決的科學問題。然後，學生在導師的指導下設計和執行此項目的實驗室實驗和/或非實驗室研究，並在學期末提交研究建議書。

研究項目應包括以下內容：

1. 以知識主導的培訓
學生應參加實驗室培訓，講習班或個別指導，其中應提供與生命科學相關的科學知識的核心知識，包括基於實驗室的的實驗設計，科學論文的閱讀和寫作以及生命科學的基本計算和統計等。

2. 以技術技能為導向的培訓
學生應安排實踐培訓，包括基於實驗室的研究技能，信息技術和數據搜索，用於數據分析的計算機軟件等。

3. 增加經驗和接觸
學生應參加各種學習活動，例如1）實驗室研究 ; 2）調查 ; 3）實地考察 ; 4）實地研究等，並學習欣賞生命科學在社會企業中的應用。

4. 團隊合作和團隊建設
學生應該學習在團隊中的人們之間進行良好協作以實現共同目標的重要性。團隊成員應該分享願景，以便在截止日期之前有效地完成項目。同樣，團隊合作的學生應該學會互相信任和互相尊重，每個成員都應該有自己的職責和責任。
courses.feedback_evaluation:
By questionnaire and focus group after the completion of the term.

學期結束後通過問卷調查和焦點小組討論。
courses.required_readings: Relevant reference materials will be provided by the supervisor.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Group Research in Life Sciences (I)
courses.description: This course is a capstone course consists of group research projects to investigate the heated topics related to Life Sciences, such that students will be inspired by how different fields of life sciences have made their impacts on the globalized knowledge-based society of Hong Kong. In this course, students form a group to carry out an independent laboratory-based/non-laboratory-based research project either provided by the supervisor or jointly decided with the group. To fulfill the course requirement, students are required to discuss their progress with their supervisors regularly and submit a research proposal. In the event that one or more member(s) of the same group will not be enrolled in LSCI4912, the remaining member(s) will continue to finish the research project with the consent ofthe supervisor.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Group Research in Life Sciences (II)

meetings.instructor: Professor NGO Chi Ki Jacky

courses.description: This course is a capstone course consists of group research projects to investigate the heated topics related to Life Sciences, such that students will be inspired by how different fields of life sciences have made their impacts on the globalized knowledge-based society of Hong Kong. Students are required to discuss their progress with their supervisor(s) regularly and submit a progress report at the end of the term. For student who will not be enrolled in LSCI 4913, a final report in the form of a manuscript and an oral presentation are assessed at the end of term for performance. In the event that one or more member(s) of the same group will not be enrolled in LSCI4913, the remaining member(s) will continue to finish the research project with the consent of the supervisor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not to be taken with BCHE4902, BIOL4902, CMBI4902, ENSC4902, FNSC4902, MBTE4902 and LSCI4000 at the same term.
courses.course_syllabus:
The students should continue to work on the research project from LSCI4910. Students should discuss the progress with their supervisors and submit a progress report in the term end. If the students will not continue to work on the research project in LSCI4912, they should submit a final report in the form of manuscript and present orally in the term end.

學生應繼續從事LSCI4910的研究項目。學生應與他們的導師討論進度，並在學期末提交進度報告。如果學生不再繼續從事LSCI4912中的研究項目，則應以論文形式提交最終報告，並在學期末作出口述報告。

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Physical Biochemistry
courses.description: This postgraduate level course provides an overview of the various biophysical methods used to decipher the molecular and structural properties of biomolecules. The course begins with an introduction into quantum mechanics to introduce the physical basis for energy levels and light absorption. It will then introduce traditional spectroscopic methods used to study the properties of biomolecules (absorption, fluorescence, phosphorescence, circular dichroism) as well as structural methods (nucleic magnetic resonance, x-ray crystallography). After describing the theory behind each method, examples will be provided from the literature to illustrate their application in real examples. Finally, a discussion of modern mass spectroscopic approaches and their uses in protein identification and protein modification will be presented.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Understand the fundamentals of the techniques used to study biomolecules

• Be able to critically assess the merits of a method and the validity of the conclusions made.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Biological Electron Microscopy and Live Cell Imaging
courses.description: This course will discuss the theory and provide hands-on practice of advanced transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and advanced live cell imaging for biological science research. Techniques covered will include TEM sample processing with high-pressure freezer, electron tomography, and live cell imaging with cutting-edge fluorescence microscopes. Emphasis will be placed on proper use of the state of the art microscopy instrument equipped in the RGC-AoE Center for Organelle Biogenesis and Function (COBF) and Centre for Cell & Developmental Biology (CCDB) of the School of Life Sciences (SLS).Students will learn the theories behind the techniques of transmission TEM, TEM sample preparation, tomography reconstruction, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and fluorescent microscopy (confocal laser scanning microscopy--CLSM and spinning disk confocal microscopy--SDCM) imaging of live cells, as well as image analysis software (e.g. Imaris). The hands-on sessions will reinforce the application of these techniques to analyze mechanisms of cellular processes. It is expected that students will be able to incorporate these techniques readily into their research, as they will practice with the instruments that the COBF and CCDB possess for their actual applications in thesis research. This course is targeted to entering postgraduate students in SLS and student registration will be limited to 20. If seats are available, second-year postgraduates students can join. This course is scheduled in the fall term (1st semester) and consists of 5 lectures (3 hours each) and 8 hands-on sessions (3 hours each), totaling 39 hours.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry, MPhil-PhD Biology, MPhil-PhD Environmental Science, MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences, MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken LSCI6303
courses.learning_outcomes: Students should understand theoretical and practical aspects on the methodology of TEM, tomography, live cell imaging, and analysis for research efforts aimed at structure-function elucidation of subcellular organelles. This course will help students combine high-resolution 3D microscopy techniques with other molecular techniques to maximize their investigative power and success potential.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to live cell imaging
2. Confocal microscopy I
3. Confocal microscopy II
4. Spinning disk confocal and super resolution microscopy, imaging analysis
5. Introduction to cellular electron microscopy, 3D electron microscopy, Installation of image analysis software, discussion
6. High pressure freezing, chemical fixation, and glass knife making
7. Ultramicrotomy, mounting, and staining
8. TEM operation
9. Tomogram calculation, modelling, and image/movie preparation I
10. Tomogram calculation, modelling, and image/movie preparation II
11. Presentation of tomography analysis results by students
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course Evaluation
* Discussion with students
courses.required_readings: Current and relevant journal articles, book chapters recommended by course teachers. It is critical for students to watch online lecture videos and lab tutorial videos before coming to classes.

courses.description: This course describes the chemical structures and biological functions of hormones in vertebrates with special emphasis on human subjects. The evolution of hormonal regulation in vertebrates, as compared with neural control, will be discussed. The organization and operation of different hypothalamus-pituitary-peripheral endocrine gland axes will be discussed. Emphasis will be placed on the molecular aspects of endocrine action. Current advances in molecular endocrinology techniques will be introduced. Students are advised to take BCHE2030 or equivalent before taking this course.

For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BCHE4130

1. Mechanisms of Hormone Action
2. Signaling, Neuro-endocrine System and Methodologies
3. Hypothalamic and Pituitary Hormones
4. Steroidogenesis
5. Actions of Adrenal Steroid Hormones
6. Pancreatic Hormone
7. Diabete Mellitus
8. Hormonal Control of Sex Differentiation and Reproduction
9. Male & Female Reproductive Physiology: Pregnancy, Parturition and Lactation
10. Growth hormone, Prolactin, and their Receptors
11. Hypothalamic-Pituitary-IGF Axis
12. Sympathoadrenal Systems and Catecholamines
13. Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Thyroid Axis
14. Thyroid Actions, Goiter and Graves Disease
15. Calcium Homeostasis and Mineralization
16. Bone Metabolism and Therapies for Disease of Calcium Homeostasis
17. Bone Metabolism: Vitamin D and Therapies for diseases of calcium homeostasis
18. Gastrointestinal Hormones: Evolution and Pathophysiology
19. Posterior Pituitary Hormones and Blood Pressure Control
20. Melatonin and the Pineal Gland: Myths and Fact

Professor CHAN Michael Kenneth

Professor CHAN Michael Kenneth

courses.description: The discipline of chemical biology is focused on the application of chemical principles, particularly organic chemistry, to the study and manipulation of biological systems. Two major focus areas include the development of chemical tools to proteins and cells, and in the identification and creation of novel compounds as therapeutics for the treatment of human disease. The course will begin with a brief review of organic chemistry fundamentals and bio-orthogonal ligand reactions. It will then cover case studies to illustrate the power of chemical biology to solve important problems at the chemistry-biology interface.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; Biology; Environmental Science; Food and Nutritional Sciences; Molecular Biotechnology; Cell Molecular Biology
Course Exclusion: BCHE3110
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge

• Recall the fundamental aspects of chirality and basic reaction mechanisms in organic chemistry.

• Know the core bio-orthogonal reactions that can be used with biological systems.

• Be aware of the important biological and biomedical problems being tackled by scientists.

• Account for how chemical biology methods are used within biomedical research and pre-clinical drug discovery.

Skill

• Students will be able to assess, evaluate and choose appropriate chemical biology methods to use in their future research studies.

Value

• Chemical biology approaches have led to advances that have led to creation of multiple active biotech companies. The knowledge gained will equip them with the skills needed to pursue careers in disciplines at the chemistry and biology interface.
courses.course_syllabus:
| Week | Topic |
| --- | --- |
| 1 | The properties of atoms and how they form bonds 1. Periodic properties (atomic and ionic radii, electron affinity, ionization energy, electronegativity) 2. Lewis theory, Atomic orbitals, hybrid orbitals and 3. Molecular Geometry |
| 2 | Organic chemistry principles relevant to biological reactions I 1. Stereochemistry 2. Nucleophiles and electrophiles 3. Nucleophilic substitution reactions (SN1 and SN2) 4. Chemical synthesis based on nucleophilic substitution reactions |
| 3 | Organic chemistry principles relevant to biological reactions II 1. Functional groups in proteins and nucleic acids 2. Nucleophilic substitution reactions in biology 3. Carboxylic acids and their derivatives 4. Chemical reactions on carboxyl groups |
| 4 | Chemical synthesis of peptides 1. Mechanism and thermodynamics of peptide bond formation 2. Protecting groups 3. Solid phase peptide synthesis 4. Native chemical ligation and their derivatives |
| 5 | Natural and bioconjugate protein reactions 1. Bioorthogonal reactions for protein labeling and conjugation 2. Expressed protein ligation 3. Isopeptide formation in biology: SpyTag/SpyCatcher reaction, ubiquitination, etc. |
| 6 | Chemistry of enzymes and coenzymes 1. Enzymes and catalysis 2. Chemistry of selected coenzymes 3. Michaelis-Menton Kinetics 4. Catalytic antibodies |
| 7 | Chemical Biology of Carbohydrates 1. Monosaccharides: structure and reactivity 2. Oligosaccharides and polysaccharides 3. Enzymatic reactions of carbohydrates |
| 8 | From genes to proteins 1. DNA Replication and RNA Transcription 2. Structure of DNA 3. Structure of RNA 4. Synthesis of proteins by protein translation |
| 9 | Directed Evolution 1. Directed Evolution of Nucleic Acids and Enzymes 2. Nucleic acid selection (SELEX) 3. Protein evolution to screen for novel properties (Phagedisplay, Yeast display, E. coli display, mRNA display) |
| 10 | Incorporating unnatural amino acids into proteins 1. Evolution of tRNA synthetases for incorporation of UAAs 2. Use of the pyrrolysine tRNA/tRNA synthetase for UAA incorporation 3. Application of UAA incorporation for biological and biotechnological studies |
| 11 | Special Topics (Novel Roles of Metals in Biology) 1. Zinc and magnesium ions in hydrolytic reactions (metalloproteases, polymerases) 2. Heme and non-heme iron proteins 3. Nickel ions in organometallic reactions 4. Molybdenum and tungsten containing enzymes 5. cis-Pt(NH3)2Cl2 as an anticancer therapeutic |
| 12 | Special Topics (Protein therapeutics and protein delivery) 1. Antibodies 2. CRISPR (Gene editing) 3. Transcription Factors (Cellular Reprogramming) 4. Strategies for overcoming the barriers to cellular delivery |
| 13 | Review and Final Examination (Weeks 7-12) |

courses.description: This course will discuss the structure and components of nervous tissue in relation to its functions. Aspects of metabolism special to the nerve and brain will be examined. These include energy metabolism, water and electrolyte balance, exchanges between blood and brain, and between brain and cerebrospinal fluid, neurotransmitters and modulators, nutrition and development of the nervous system, neuroendocrinology and the biochemistry of mental diseases.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BCHE4040
courses.learning_outcomes:
After reading this course, students areexpected be able to:
- Outline the special features of the nervous system and itscomponents.
- Describe the functions of the nervous system both at the cellularand molecular levels.
- Explain how neurons communicate with each other in cellular andmolecular terms.
- Explain the pathophysiology of certain neurological andneuropsychiatric disorders, and the biochemical basis of treating them.

1. Structureand function of the central nervous system.
2. Cells ofthe nervous system
3. Myelin:
a. Structure and function
b. Biosynthesis and genesregulating its biosynthesis

4. Biochemistry, physiology and pharmacology of transport system:
a. Blood-brain-CSF barriers
b. Cellular (Membrane) transport
c. Axoplasmic transport
5. Ionchannels, potentials and signal conduction
6. Briefintroduction of neurochemical techniques:
a.Preparation of brain slice
b.Preparation of synaptosomes
c.Chemical and surgical lesion
d.Tissue culture
e.Molecular biology
7. Metabolism:
a. Brief review of brainmetabolism
b. Some inherited neurologicaldiseases related to metabolic disorders
c. Nutrition and brain function
8. Biochemistry, physiology andpharmacology of synaptic transmission:
a. Classification ofneurotransmitters
b. Biosynthesis of transmittersand their regulation
c. Termination ofneurotransmission
d. Properties and molecularbiology of receptors
e. 2nd messengers and signaltransduction
f. Modulation of signaltransmission
9. Biochemistry and molecular biology of neurological and psychiatric disorders:
a. Myasthenia gravis
b. Parkinson's disease
c. Alzheimer's disease
d. Huntington's disease

courses.description: This course aims at providing students with the essential concepts of basic and applied immunology. Topics to be covered include architecture and development of the immune system, antigens and antibodies, immunoglobulin genes and diversity, the major histocompatibility system and T cell receptors, tolerance and autoimmunity, and integration of immune responses. The effector mechanisms of the immune system will be introduced, with special emphasis on the role of innate and acquired immunity in health and disease. The relationship of immunology to clinical problems of infectious disease, immunodeficiency, hypersensitivity, transplantation and cancer will be discussed. The applications of immunology to modern medicine and biotechnology, including vaccination, monoclonal antibody production and antibody engineering will also be covered. Students are advised to take BCHE2030 or equivalent before taking this course.

courses.title: Methods in Biochemistry
courses.description: This course will allow students to gain theoretical and practical, hands-on knowledge of various advanced research methodologies and their applications in biochemical research and pre-clinical services. Methods include: • Ion exchange chromatography • Spectrophotometry • SDS-Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis • Enzymatic assay • DNA cloning technologies and DNA electrophoresis • PCR and site-directed mutagenesis • Bacterial transformation and culture • Recombinant protein expression and purification • Human cell culture and cytotoxicity assay • Fluorescence technology: and flow cytometry, confocal microscopy, fluorescence spectrum scanning and measurement
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BBMS6200
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:
1) Describe the concepts of modern analytical and instrumental techniques relevant to measurements in biochemical research and pre-clinical services.
2) Master a number of biochemical techniques such as polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis, enzymatic assay, DNA electrophoresis and DNA fingerprinting , PCR and polymorphism analysis, human cell culture and cytotoxicity assay, ELISA and flow cytometry, Rasmol and computer tools for analysis, Bacterial transformation and test for food contamination, statistical analysis of toxic chemicals in environment and fermentation technology.
3) Justify the selection of different bio-analytical methods to characterize the composition of a complex sample.
4) Critically evaluate the merits, limitations and future trends of various biochemical analytical techniques.
5) Work in a collaborative manner with others on a team, contributing to the management, planning and implementation of a task.
6) Demonstrate a commitment to professional integrity and ethical behavior consistent with the missions of the university and accepted standards of professional conduct.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Evolutionary Biology

meetings.instructor: Professor Michael David PITTMAN

courses.description: This course introduces students to the pattern and processes of evolution. The course begins with an introduction of the history and philosophy of evolutionary ideas, followed by the genetics of adaptation, natural selection and speciation, and then on to the geological record and the fossil record of origination and extinction, and finishes with a discussion of the principle and practice of phylogenetic analyses and the molecular basis of evolution. Case studies on the use of molecular data in the study of evolutionary processes, biogeography and the history of life (including human evolution) will be included. This course is specially designed for advanced level of undergraduates, not only because of the course content, but it requires the students to think and integrate knowledge learnt from different courses in biology, molecular biology, cell biology, biotechnology, genetics, ecology, etc. In addition, a problem will be initiated by students and to be solved via searching for knowledge and information from diverse channels not only limited to scientific journal articles. Furthermore, a voluntary/optional field trip is organized for the students to define the problem of their own interests. These will help students to understand and analyse the problems from various aspects and multiple angles. Feedbacks will be provided throughout the course at different checkpoints.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BIOL4010
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge
• understand the key concepts in evolutionary biology
• understand and evaluate the research methods in evolutionary biology
• understand the principle and practice of phylogenetic analysis and its relationships to biological classification
• understand the molecular basis of evolution and the use of molecular data in studies on evolutionary processes, biogeography, and the history of life
• understand the linkage between the modern theory of evolution and other biological disciplines such as zoology, botany, genetics, ecology and molecular biology

Skill
• understand and communicate ideas in biological evolution to individuals with or without scientific background

Value
• Appreciate the importance of evolutionary analysis in areas including medicine, conservation biology and arthropology
• Familiar with important questions and key issues in evolutionary biology
courses.course_syllabus:
1. History of evolutionary theory
2. Variation/Adaptation/Natural selection
3. Population genetics
4. Species concepts
5. Reproductive isolation mechanisms
6. Speciation
7. Classification and phylogeny
8. Molecular evolution and phylogenetics
9. Introduction
10. Molecular tools and data interpretation
11. History of the use of molecular data in evolutionary studies
12. Genetic variations in natural populations and gene flow
13. Species phylogeny and macroevolution
14. Fossil record
15. History of biodiversity
16. Rates of evolution
17. Extinction & mass extinction

Students are expected to revise the teaching materials after every single lecture, as the concepts keep building on each other as the course proceeds.
Students are also expected to keep reading different scientific research papers throughout the course for preparation and hand-in the essay of any topics related to evolutionary biology. At the end of September, students are required to hand in the title and 3 key references of his/her own chosen topic based on interests. At the end of October, the students are required to hand in an abstract of the essay. And at the end of November, students will be handing the final essay of their own chosen topics. Students will appreciate the importance of evolutionary analysis in other disciplines such as medicine, conservation biology and arthropology; and also get familiar with important questions and key issues in evolutionary biology.

courses.description: This course deals with the principles and concepts of developmental biology. Topics include analysis of fundamental embryological process and consideration of major developmental biological problems such as cell fate determination, cell differentiation, pattern formation, morphogenesis, organogenesis, hormonal and environmental control of development in model organisms. Selected current topics and technology in developmental biology will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BIOL4120
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will acquire fundamental concepts and knowledge of developmental biology including cell fate determination, cell differentiation, body pattern formation, morphogenesis, organ formation, the molecular regulatory mechanisms of different developmental processes in different model organisms.
2. Students will acquire ability to comprehend the implication and application of developmental biology in the medical and biotechnology field.
3. Students will be introduced to the critical experimental evidence and current technology that has led to the formulation of the central concepts and novel findings in developmental biology. Thus, the students can learn how a biological question can be solved through experimental design and process.
4. Students will acquire skills in literature survey from various sources, analytical and problem solving skills through the course assessment.
5. This course equips students with the essential knowledge for studying the more advanced degree in biological science.
6. Students will acquire an educated mind and responsible attitude to judge on the application of latest developmental biological technique and findings in medical and biotechnology field for the good of human society and natural environment.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Global Change Biology
courses.description: This course will discuss the impact of global environmental changes on biological systems and their ecosystem services. We will focus on how global warming, and associated changes such as altered rainfall, sea level rise, and ocean acidification, have changed the biological communities of the Earth’s various ecosystems, from forests to coral reefs. The impact at biological levels from molecules to cells, organisms, populations, and communities will be explored. Models for projecting future changes in Earth systems, biological communities and ecosystem services under climate change will be introduced. While the major focus is on climate change, other aspects of global environmental change, such as habitat deterioration, will also be considered. Students are required to present case studies of global change biology based on latest research findings.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BIOL4230
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge
• An understanding of fundamental topics in global change biology, including: the Earth system; changes in the physiology of organisms under altered environmental conditions; community and ecosystem responses; the human aspect; multiple stressors
• A recognition of the links between impacts on different levels of biological organization; from molecules to cells, organisms, populations, and communities

Skill
• Development of generic skills necessary in Life Science fields including the ability to research a topic independently, find and synthesize information from literature, ask critical questions
• An introduction to approaches used to project future climates and organism/ecosystem responses

Value
• An appreciation of current environmental changes that are unique relative to other periods in Earth history, and how these changes may impact ecosystem services that humans rely upon
• Recognition that local human actions may mitigate largely-unmanageable effects of global change
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction – understanding the Earth system
1. The Earth system and natural/historical drivers and patterns of change (both in terms of climate, and biological responses)
2. Major features of present/future climate, including human-driven change (scenarios, models, validation, projections)
3. Approaches to monitor current and anticipate future biological change

II. Changes in organism physiology under altered conditions
1. Photosynthesis
2. Nutrient- and water-use efficiencies
3. Growth and reproduction
4. Phenology
5. Plant/algal quality and defenses

III. Community and ecosystem impacts of human-driven change
1. Population responses – e.g. range shifts
2. Community responses – e.g. alteration of species interactions; composition and diversity; parasites and pathogens
3. Ecosystem change – e.g. regime shifts; changes in net primary productivity, respiration, net ecosystem productivity, and nutrient cycling

IV. The human aspect
1. Anticipated impacts on humans – ecosystem services
2. Implications for conservation (adaptation of strategies, connectivity and landscape management, species management)
3. International policy (international climate policy, mitigation, carbon sinks and sources, assessing risks and designing solutions)

V. Additional considerations – multiple stressors
1. Non-climate change – e.g. habitat deterioration, pollution, over-fishing, species introductions, development
2. Interactive effects and feedbacks
3. Implications for management (rehabilitation and recovery)

courses.description: This course brings the students to the marine microbial biosphere. Microbes are the engines that drive carbon and nutrient cycles in the ocean, and influence the health of marine plants and animals. In this course, we will discuss major concepts in ecological studies of microbes in the ocean, the way microbes function in their natural environments, and how their activities influence ecosystem functioning, global climate and the Earth as human habitat.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Protein Trafficking

meetings.instructor: Professor ZHUANG Xiaohong

courses.description: This course covers the general principles of and current developments in protein trafficking for both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Specific topics include the structures and functions of transport vesicles, receptor-mediated protein transport, protein compartmentation in the secretory and endocytic pathways as well as in other organelles, protein degradation and the biological consequences of protein mis-localization in organisms. Students are required to watch online Lecture Videos in KEEP or Blackboard about Basic Knowledge in protein trafficking prior to the Lectures. These online Lecture Videos are supplemented with online quizzes in which students need to finish after watching these videos. In addition, students will also watch videos discussing recent Research Papers. During lectures, students will have in-depth discussion regarding the questions, key concepts and up-to-date research. By these means students will be able to clarify their concepts and be familiar with the latest research findings that are related to protein trafficking. Students will also learn the current developments of protein trafficking in details by delivering a presentation on a relevant topic derived from a recent research paper, with a Q&A session. The presentation will be graded by both Professor and peer students.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken CMBI4001
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students taking this course are expected to achieve the following:
1) To understand the molecular mechanism of vesicular transport
2) To appreciate the rapid and current development in cellular trafficking
3) To acquire and appreciate the most up-to-date cellular technology and research methods
4) To synthesize new ideas from their knowledge on protein trafficking in research
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics:
I. Introduction
II. Basic concepts of protein trafficking in eukaryotic cells
III. Basic techniques and new technology for studying protein trafficking
IV. Discussion on selective landmark or classical papers
V. Discussion on selective current papers
VI. Self-learning & learning via teaching (student presentation and discussion)

1) Course evaluation at the end of the course
2) Direct feedback from students to teacher

courses.recommended_readings: Current papers provided or recommended by the teacher

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Protein Folding

meetings.instructor: Professor WONG Kam Bo
Professor WONG Kam Bo

courses.description: This course covers the energetics of protein folding including hydrophobic effect, hydrogen bond, electrostatic interactions, and conformational entropy, and how these factors interplay in protein folding and functions. Through detailed in-class discussion on the classic and the latest research literatures, students will learn how important theories and hypotheses of protein folding energetics were formulated, supported or disproved by experiments. The students will also learn how to apply the theories to improve protein stability in protein design and engineering through a group project.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken CMBI4002
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to achieve the following:
1) To understand the energetics of protein folding, including hydrophobic effect, hydrogen bond, electrostatic interactions, and
conformational entropy
2) To understand how these energetic factors affect protein stability
3) To apply their knowledge learned in the design/engineering of proteins with improved protein stability
4) To synthesize new ideas from their knowledge on protein folding in research
courses.course_syllabus:
Stage 1: Learn how to address scientific problems by studying research literatures
We aim to teach students on how to formulate and support their hypothesis in protein folding research by good examples of research. We start with the classical protein folding experiments of Anfinsen who lead to the Nobel Prize in 1972, to the latest research on protein folding energetics. The students are challenged with open-end questions on how to address key questions on energetic factors that contribute to protein stability. Through intensive in-class discussions and quizzes, the students will learn how hypotheses on protein folding are supported or disproved by experimental evidence. Examples also include those published by scientists in Hong Kong so that the students have a more personal touch on how scientists innovate and design their researches.
Stage 2: Learn how to apply the theories learnt to improve protein stability in a group project.
The students are divided into small groups and work together on a group project to study how to improve protein stability using the theory of protein folding energetic learnt. They will survey the latest research literatures on the field and are asked to give critical assessment on how protein stability can be improved and present their views and findings in an oral presentation.

1) Course evaluation at the end of the course
2) Direct feedback from students to teacher

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Environmental Health
courses.description: This course introduces the contemporary problems and issues in environmentally dependent aspects of health. Broad coverage of health effects of foodborne, airborne and waterborne pollutants, pesticides, and consumer product are considered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken ENSC4250
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course is designed to give students an overview of the sources, modes of action, and health effects of the global and local important pollutants including pesticides, food additives, transgenes in genetically modified foods, environmental tobacco smoke, indoor air pollutants, water pollutants, peroxisome proliferators, environmental estrogens, and benzene. After the study, the student should be able to:
1. Describe the sources of the pollutants
2. Understand the modes of action of the pollutants
3. Familiar with the symptoms and human health effects resulting from exposure to the pollutants
4. Discuss ways to reduce our exposure to the pollutants
courses.course_syllabus:
•Pesticides
•Food additives
•Genetic modified foods
•Environmental tobacco smoke
•Indoor air pollutants
•Drinking water quality and health
•Peroxisome proliferators
•Environmental estrogens
•Occupational chemical hazards
courses.feedback_evaluation:

2. The discussion with the student representatives during the Staff-Student Consultative Committee

courses.description: This course is the first part of a two-semester physiology series.  This course covers the main physiological systems of the human body.  By the completion of these courses, students should understand how the organ systems taught in our body function and regulate; they should be able to describe in detail how the taught organs work together to maintain homeostasis.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken FNSC4101
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
i. understand the functions of different organ systems,
ii. integrate the physiological functions in the taught systems, and
iii. apply the physiological conditions in diseases.

Objectives for student development:
1. Integrate the physiology of the taught organ systems.
2. Prepare students for the second part of the series.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction – Basic Chemistry/Biology Review [Chapter 1]
Introduction to Human Physiology
Basic Chemistry/ Biology Review
Homeostasis and homeostatic control system
Week 2 Cell Physiology I [Chapter 2-3]
An overview of Cell Structure
Molecular Interactions
Compartmentation: Cells and Tissues
Week 3 Cell Physiology II [Chapter 4-6]
Energy and Cellular Metabolism
Membrane Dynamics
Communication, Integration and Homeostasis
Week 4 Nervous System I [Chapters 8-11]
Introduction to nervous system
Membrane and Action Potentials
AP conduction and synaptic transmission
Week 5 Nervous System II [Chapters 8-11]
Central Nervous System
Spinal Cord, Brain and Brain Function
Autonomic and Somatic Motor Control
Week 6 Mid-term Examination
Week 7 Sensory Physiology [Chapters 8-11]
Introduction to the Human Sensory System
Receptor Physiology and Pain
The Senses of Vision, Hearing, Balance, Smell and Taste
Control of Food Intake
Week 8 Muscle Physiology [Chapter 12]
Structure of Skeletal Muscle
Muscle tissue, Neuro-muscular Control and the Mechanics
Spinal Reflex and Control of Motor Movement
Week 9 Cardiac Physiology [Chapters 14-15, 17-18]
Anatomy of the Heart
Cardiac Cycle and Contraction of Myocardium
Cardiac electrophysiology
Week 10 Vascular Physiology [Chapters 14-15, 17-18]
Structure of Vascular Wall
Regulation of Vascular Tone
Arterial, Venous, Lymphatic Blood Vessels
Week 11 Blood, Immune, and Lymphoid Organs [Chapters 16, 24]
Overview of structural components
Hematopoiesis and blood clotting
Mechanism of immune defense: innate and adaptive
Role of lymphoid organs
Week 12 Energy Balance and Thermoregulation [Chapter 22]
Role of energy balance and energy storage – adipose tissue
Burning energy to produce heat: UCP1
Week 13 Immunometabolism [Chapter 22]
Role of immune cells in sensing temperature
Obesity and chronic inflammation
Brown, white, beige adipose tissue interactions with immune cells
Week 14 Final Examination

courses.description: This course is a continuation of a two-semester physiology series.  This physiology course complements the other organ systems taught in the first semester.  By the completion of these courses, students should have the whole picture of the organ systems in our body; they should be able to describe in detail how these organs work together to maintain homeostasis, thus keeping us alive and healthy.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken FNSC4102
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
i. understand the functions of different organ systems,
ii. integrate the physiological functions in various systems, and
iii. apply the physiological conditions in diseases.

Objectives for student development:
1. Integrate the physiology of various organ systems.
2. Prepare students for pursuing a higher degree in healthcare profession.

Week 1 Endocrine System I [Chapters 7, 23]
Introduction to hormones
- Endocrine glands
Week 2 Endocrine System II [Chapters 7, 23]
- Endocrine, paracrine, juxtacrine signaling
- Hormone production, release, and control
- Hormone interactions
Week 3 Gastrointestinal Physiology I [Chapter 21]
- Overall anatomy of the digestive system
- Regulation of GI function
Week 4 Gastrointestinal Physiology II [Chapter 21]
- Biochemical processing/digestion of food
- Mechanism: Absorption of key metabolites in GI tract
Week 5 Metabolism and Energy Balance [Chapter 22]
- Overview of metabolic chemical reactions i.e. ATP production
- Fed vs fast metabolic response
- Metabolic dysregulation – diabetes and obesity
Week 6 Mid-term Examination
Week 7 Renal System I [Chapter 19, 20]
- Anatomy of the Renal system
- Kidneys: Functionality
- Osmolarity and acid-base homeostasis
Week 8 Renal System II [Chapter 19, 20]
- Filtration and Reabsorption of waste and nutrients

Week 9 Respiratory System [Chapters 17-18]

- Mechanics of breathing
- Gas exchange and transport
Week 10 Fluid and Acid-Base Balance [Chapter 20]
- Expansion on acid-base control in the body
- Control of water and other essential salt balance
Week 11 Skeletal System [Chapter 12]
- Overview of bone structure
- Biomechanics of bone
- Osteoclast/osteoblast: bone stress-based remodeling
Week 12 Exercise [Chapter 25]
- Metabolism and Exercise

courses.description: This course applies the knowledge of the physical and chemical behavior of food components in the context of food manufacturing and storage, with emphasis on both safety and nutritional attributes. courses.description: This course explores the origins and etiology, dietary therapies and population-based strategies to overcome the nutrition-related chronic disease burden globally, regionally and in Hong Kong. Multidisciplinary researchers and practitioners will discuss how modern culture, including food consumption and lifestyles, produces this noncommunicable disease burden, leaving governments challenged to fnd effective policy solutions.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken FNSC5120
courses.learning_outcomes:
After this course, the students will be able to
- understand how nutrition transition will affect our diet by referring to historical, cultural, biological, and economical aspects
- describe how modern diets and lifestyle give rise to the global and local epidemic and individual/societal burdens of non-communicable diseases (NCD)
- recognize the influence of NCD on individual's nutritional status and describe role of medical nutrition therapy (MNT) in the management and treatment of NCD such as cancer, diabetes and metabolic syndrome, obesity, osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, and renal disease etc.
- describe the role of nutrition in health care, the nutrition care process and methods of nutrition assessment, specialized nutrition support and geriatric nutrition

Ms. SIN Man Ching,

courses.description: This module covers various aspects of nutrition, ranging from biochemistry to nutrition for the lifespan. The content aims to integrate fundamental knowledge into dietary practices in everyday life. The development and prevention of chronic diseases in the context of nutrition will also be discussed. Recent popular topics, such as obesity, trans fat, etc, are also introduced. At the end of this module, students should be able to state the basic biological mechanisms in maintaining a body through good nutrition.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken FNSC5220
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the students are able to describe the biochemical and physiological significance of the nutrients. They should also understand and integrate the requirements of various nutrients in different stages of life. Moreover, the students should also be able to explain the effect of nutrients on the immune system development and functioning throughout the life cycle. They should be able to work as a group and locate the resources of information for researching on a subject in relation to nutrition and diseases.
courses.course_syllabus: This module covers various aspects of nutrition, ranging from biochemistry to nutrition for the elderly. The content aims to integrate fundamental knowledge into dietary practices in everyday life. The development and prevention of chronic diseases in the context of nutrition will also be discussed. Recent popular topics, such as obesity, *trans* fat, etc, are also introduced. At the end of this module, students should be able to state the basic biological mechanisms in maintaining a healthy body through prudent nutrition.

courses.description: In this course, the physiological aspects of nutrition will be introduced. The course covers how nutrients may affect human physiologically in an organ-specific manner. Malnutrition can be interpreted as over- or under-nutrition. Together with the basic understanding of human anatomy and physiology, the pathophysiological impact of malnourishment will be discussed. Gastrointestinal, renal, cardiovascular, respiratory and endocrine systems will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken FNSC5320
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the students are able to describe the human physiology in relation to nutrient metabolism. They should also understand and integrate the effect of nutrients on some chronic disease development, such as cardiovascular diseases. Moreover, the students should also be able to explain how our body is handling the food ingested, how the nutrients are used in exercising, and how the food consumed may affect our brain development, etc. After all, the students should be familiar with the interplay between nutrients consumed and our organ system. They should be able to work as a group and locate the resources of information for researching on a subject in relation to nutrition and physiology.

3. Nutrient Retention in the Kidneys

8. Nutrition and Microorganisms in the Gut

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Food Toxicology & Safety

meetings.instructor:
Dr. LI Yuk Man, 
Mr CHEUNG Chi Leung

courses.description: Food can be contaminated at any stage of its production and handling with naturally occurring toxicants and/or man-made chemicals that have adverse health effects to humans. The objective of this course is to gain knowledge on the key concepts and principles of food safety and toxicology. Students are expected to develop an understanding of the nature and properties of the toxic substances in foods as well as the nature and magnitude of the hazard they represent to humans, with the aim of preventing health risks due to food intake. Topics on food safety include food hygiene, food poisoning, food legislation and food safety control systems. Topics on food toxicology include its general principles, biochemical and physiological mechanisms of action of food toxicants, and methods for food safety assessment. Emphasis will be placed on the evaluation of current issues in food safety toxicology including risk assessment and management.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken FNSC5430
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. gain knowledge on the key concepts and principles of food safety and toxicology
2. understand the nature and properties of the toxic substances in foods as well as the nature and magnitude of the hazard they represent to humans,
3. understand the general principles, biochemical and physiological mechanisms of action of food toxicants, and methods for food safety assessment
4. understand the basic principles of food hygiene and food poisoning to prevent health risks due to food intake.
5. understand food legislation and food safety control systems, as well as risk analysis
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Food Toxicology and Health Risk Management
2. Natural Toxins
3. Metal Intoxication
4. Pesticides and Trace Organics
5. Food Additives and Novel Foods
6. Food Adulteration and Current Issues
7. Food and Environmental Hygiene
8. Food poisoning and spoilage
9. Food Legislations
10. Food Safety Control
11. Risk Management in Food Safety

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Medical Biotechnology
courses.description: The field of medical biotechnology is experiencing rapid growth in recent years, leading to the development of innovative techniques for diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of diseases. With the basis in gene manipulation and cell culture, innovations in biomolecular therapies such as recombinant proteins, monoclonal antibodies, vaccines, nucleic acid therapies, and regenerative medicines are developed. These significantly improve human health. The course is designed to give students an insight into the principles and techniques leading to these innovations. Safety and ethical issues will also be discussed. Topics include: 1) History of Medical Biotechnology; 2) High-throughput technologies in molecular diagnosis I and II;3) Clinical sequencing in infectious disease control; 4) Clinical sequencing and precision medicine; 5) Protein therapeutics (pharmaceuticals, recombinant antibodies and enzymes); 6) Nucleic acids therapeutic agents and gene therapy; 7) Current vaccine design; 8) Stem cells and regenerative medicine; 9) Nanoparticles in medicine
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken MBTE3510
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe the basic principles and techniques of medical biotechnology.
2. Understand the mechanisms whereby the therapeutic molecules and diagnostic tools work.
3. Evaluate the use of medical biotechnology towards the modern society.
4. Appreciate the range of therapeutic molecules and diagnostic tools developed by the biotechnology industry over the last few years.
5. Realize the potential safety and ethical issues on these technologies on human health.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: 1) History of Medical Biotechnology; 2) High-throughput technologies in molecular diagnosis I and II; 3) Clinical sequencing in infectious disease control; 4) Clinical sequencing and precision medicine; 5) Protein therapeutics (pharmaceuticals, recombinant antibodies and enzymes); 6) Nucleic acids therapeutic agents and gene therapy; 7) Current vaccine design; 8) Stem cells and regenerative medicine; 9) Nanoparticles in medicine.

courses.required_readings: Nil.
courses.recommended_readings: Glick, Bernard R ; Patten, Cheryl L ; Delovitch, T. L (2014) Medical Biotechnology, Washington, DC: ASM Press.
