courses.description: The course will provide an extended understanding on the basic concepts, applications, and strategies of genetic engineering. Contents include a comprehensive introduction of recombinant DNA technology, selected techniques for genomic and functional genomic studies, and an overview on organism cloning and transgenic organisms.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken MBTE4320
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcomes:
1. Acquire core knowledge on molecular cloning: the concepts of gene cloning, hybridization and blotting, screening and construction of gene libraries.
2. Acquire updated information on DNA sequencing and application of PCR.
3. Acquire ability to understand different approaches to study gene functions.
4. Acquire understanding of organism cloning and transgenic organisms, including the principles and potential applications.

Skills outcomes:
1. Acquire skills in literature survey using various sources including effective usage of information technologies and web-based searches;
2. Acquire good analytical and oral communication skills via class project presentation;
3. Acquire good problem solving skill via course assessment.

Values and attitude outcomes:
1. Acquire a positive attitude toward genetic engineering;
2. Acquire an educated mind and responsible attitude to judge the pros and cons of various applications of genetic engineering to the human society and natural environment.

courses.description: This course is to prepare students with interests in higher level molecular biology based plant biotechnology. Students enrolled in this course will study the principles of traditional breeding from the molecular biological perspectives; gene discovery by forward and reverse genetics with emphasis on T-DNA and transposons and their application in functional genomics; principles and applications of plant genomics and epigenomics; transgenic technology with detailed discussion on current development of marker-free, gene silencing and RNA interference, and gene stackediting technologies; and application of plant biotechnology with reference to actual examples and relevant industrial perspectives. In addition, food and environmental safety concerns related to genetically-modified crops will be discussed.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Microbial Biotechnology
courses.description: Knowledge in microbial technology is growing exponentially throughout the discovery of novel sequences of hundreds of microorganisms and the advancement of new technologies, such as genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics and metabolomics. This course examines the application of the latest technologies in microbial biotechnology to environment, agriculture, industry and medicine. Selected topics include applied microbial physiology; genetic manipulation through applied genetics and genetic engineering; genomics and proteomics; metabolomics and biosynthetic pathway analysis and industrial fermentation technology and enzyme technology. Examples of applications include microbial production of single-cell proteins, protein engineering, primary and secondary metabolites. Plant/animal – microbe interactions and microbial technology in biocatalysis, biodegradation and bioremediation will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Biotechnology for Environment and Business Sustainability

meetings.instructor: Professor TSUI Tsz Ki Martin

courses.description: This course aims to take students to explore the theory and case studies in environmental biotechnology on a wide range of applications, including pollution removal, renewable energy, biomass production, ecological restoration, sustainable farming, monitoring of environmental quality, environmental-friendly products, etc. The course will include basic concepts of ecology, environmental sciences, microbiology, plant and animal sciences, ecotoxicology, and environmental sustainability. The applications of the knowledge of environmental biotechnology on global business sustainability will be discussed through case studies and literature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Environmental Science; or MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sci; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell & Molecular Bio; or MSc Sustainable Glo Bus; or MSc Bio, Env Mgt, Sustn & Tech
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:

[1] understand the fundamental processes in global environmental pollution and the control management.

[2] understand the basic concepts and recent development in environmental biotechnology and its relationships to global sustainability solution.

[3] know how to design and conduct environmental biotechnology project in solving some environmental problems.

[4] know how to communicate with the business sector with a scientific understanding of environmental biotechnology, and apply the concept to the business sustainability.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course presents the recent understanding and advancements in environmental biotechnology and its applications in sustainability. The lectures are on a range of topics, covering fundamentals of environmental pollution, environmental biotechnology utilizing microbes and plants in pollutant sequestration, environmental sustainability, business approaches to environmental protection and sustainability, etc. Advanced concepts of application of environmental biotechnology will be further discussed with an emphasis on business sustainability, environmental pollution and health, and global climate change.

| Week 1 | Course introduction, and overview of global environmental problems |
| --- | --- |
| Week 2 | Introduction to environmental biotechnology and environmental sustainability |
| Week 3 | Principles of environmental problems- chemical pollution, climate change, land and ocean degradation, biodiversity decline, and over-consumerism |
| Week 4 | Pollution remediation using live organisms - toxicants and carbon |
| Week 5 | Ecological restoration and species rescue using a biotechnological approach |
| Week 6 | Monitoring of the environment and production of green-products and personal health care products using biological components |
| Week 7 | Review and/or midterm exam |
| Week 8 | What is Environmental Social Governance (ESG)? What roles can environmental biotechnology play in ESG? |
| Week 9 | The technological demand for responding to ESG, climate change, and environmental sustainability |
| Week 10 | Potential applications of environmental biotechnology in business sustainability; individual/group projects initiate |
| Week 11 | Future ideas of environmental biotechnology and their potential applications in business sustainability |
| Week 12 | Project presentation and discussion (i): Case studies of business sustainability during environmental disasters |
| Week 13 | Project presentation and discussion (ii): Case studies of business sustainability under climate change |
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Course Evaluation

- Discussion with students
courses.required_readings: Lecture handout for each of the topics will be uploaded to the accompanied Blackboard site. Extra reading materials are expected to change every year to reflect the latest development in the research field in environmental biotechnology and business sustainability. Additional reading materials such as journal articles will be provided by individual instructor.

2. Scott T. Young and Kanwalroop Kathy Dhanda. 2015. Sustainability: Essentials for Business First Edition. Sage Publications. (Paperback ISBN: 978-1412982849)

courses.title: Techniques in Gene Engineering and Detection of Gene Expression

meetings.instructor: Professor NGO Chi Ki Jacky

courses.description: This course will introduce the fundamentals of CRISPR and its application in genetic engineering. Students will learn to design CRISPR targets using bioinformatics tools, to generate gene knockouts/knock-ins, and to validate the results using the most current technologies. The bioethics of genome editing will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Environmental Science; or MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will be able to:
1. Describe the basic mechanism that underlies the CRISPR technology.
2. Design and perform genetic engineering experiments using CRISPR.
3. Validate the outcome of the genome editing experiments.
4. Plan and perform real-time qPCR and Western Blot for examination of mRNA and protein expression.
5. Critically assess the safety and ethical issues of genome editing experiments.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 - CRISPR immunity and DNA repair mechanisms.
Week 2 - Genome editing: gRNA design, off-target effects and strategies to overcome them.
Week 3 – Strategies to detect and validate the results of CRISRP. Technologies to examine gene expression: RT-qPCR and Western Blot.
Week 4 - CRISPR applications: Human therapeutics. Bioethics and policy of genome editing.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Techniques in Biological Electron Microscopy and Live Cell Imaging

meetings.instructor:
Professor KANG Byung Ho, 
Professor ZHUANG Xiaohong

courses.description: This course will discuss the theory and provide hands-on practice of advanced transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and advanced live cell imaging for biological science research. Techniques covered will include TEM sample processing with high-pressure freezer, electron tomography, and live cell imaging with cutting-edge fluorescence microscopes. Emphasis will be placed on proper use of the state of the art microscopy instrument equipped in the RGC-AoE Center for Organelle Biogenesis and Function (COBF) and Centre for Cell & Developmental Biology (CCDB) of the School of Life Sciences (SLS). Students will learn the theories behind the techniques of transmission TEM, TEM sample preparation, tomography reconstruction, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and fluorescent microscopy (confocal laser scanning microscopy--CLSM and spinning disk confocal microscopy--SDCM) imaging of live cells, as well as image analysis software (e.g. Imaris). The hands-on sessions will reinforce the application of these techniques to analyze mechanisms of cellular processes. It is expected that students will be able to incorporate these techniques readily into their research, as they will practice with the instruments that the COBF and CCDB possess for their actual applications in thesis research. This course is targeted to entering postgraduate students in SLS and student registration will be limited to 20. If seats are available, second-year postgraduates students can join. This course is scheduled in the fall term (1st semester) and consists of 4 lectures (3 hours each) and 8 hands-on sessions (3 hours each), totaling 36 hours.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken LSCI5012
courses.learning_outcomes: Students should understand theoretical and practical aspects on the methodology of TEM, tomography, live cell imaging, and analysis for research efforts aimed at structure-function elucidation of subcellular organelles. This course will help students combine high-resolution 3D microscopy techniques with other molecular techniques to maximize their investigative power and success potential.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to live cell imaging
2. Confocal microscopy I
3. Confocal microscopy II
4. Spinning disk confocal and super resolution microscopy, imaging analysis
5. Introduction to cellular electron microscopy, 3D electron microscopy, installation of image analysis software, discussion
6. High pressure freezing, chemical fixation, and glass knife making
7. Ultramicrotomy, mounting, and staining
8. TEM operation
9. Tomogram calculation, modelling, and image/movie preparation I
10. Tomogram calculation, modelling, and image/movie preparation II
11. Presentation of tomography analysis results by students
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course Evaluation
* Discussion with students

courses.recommended_readings: Current and relevant journal articles recommended by course teachers.

courses.description: Students will be introduced to the theory and principle of common contemporary research techniques in marine biology and ecology. By the end of the course, students will be able to:
- explain the principle and practice of the common techniques employed in contemporary marine biological and ecological research
- select and apply appropriate techniques to their own research project
courses.course_syllabus:
- Maintaining indoor/outdoor culture and experimental systems for marine biological and ecological research
- Stable isotope analysis in marine ecology
- Underwater surveying and sampling techniques
- Marine toxicity testing and risk assessment
- Molecular techniques in marine biology and ecology: genomes and e-DNA
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course Evaluation
* Discussion with students
courses.required_readings: Relevant journal articles and other reading materials to be distributed by instructors.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Techniques in Plant Sciences
courses.description: This course teaches theory and skills used in modern plant physiology, plant cell signaling, and plant cellular and molecular biology researches.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Environmental Science; or MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will learn and master the abilities to:
1. identify and explain key research methodologies in different areas of plant sciences
2. design methods and experiments to investigate research questions in plant sciences
3. apply research methods for sampling and data collection
4. analyse and present research data
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 (12 hours)

* Overview of transient expression systems in plant cells
* Techniques for using transient expression systems for studying protein stability and trafficking in plant cells

Week 2 (12 hours)

* Overview of plant genetic engineering and transgenic plants
* Molecular techniques for transgenic plant analyses

Week 3 (12 hours)

* Overview of protein-protein and protein-DNA interaction studies in plants
* *In vitro* and *in vivo* techniques for studying protein-protein or protein-DNA interaction in plants

Week 4 (3 hours)

* Presentation of course learning experience and results
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course Evaluation
* Discussion with students
courses.required_readings: Current and relevant journal articles related to plant sciences as selected by instructors.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Techniques in NGS Sequencing Library Preparation
courses.description: This course contains lectures and laboratory practice sections related to sequencing techniques in genomics, transcriptomics, and epigenetics. This course will focus on molecular biology experiment methods (aka wet lab skills) such as genomic DNA sequencing, RNA-Seq, small RNA-Seq, chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-Seq), DNaseI-Seq, ATAC-Seq and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing. In addition, a genomic technology known as optical mapping that is complementary to sequencing will also be discussed and performed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.learning_outcomes:
The students will be able to perform

1. DNA-Seq

2. RNA-Seq and sRNA-Seq

3. ChIP-Seq and DAP-Seq

4. DNaseI-Seq and ATAC-Seq

5. WGBS-Seq

6. Optical mapping analysis
courses.course_syllabus: The purpose of this course is to get an in-depth understanding in the molecular basis of current NGS techniques with a special focus on different strategies related Illumina sequencing library preparation. Advantages and disadvantages of current sequencing technologies and their implications on the sequencing result implication will be discussed. The course layout has been adapted to the needs of beginners in the field of NGS. However, molecular biology background is required.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course Evaluation
* Discussion with students
courses.required_readings:
* Current Protocols in Molecular Biology
* Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Techniques in Molecular Marine Ecology

meetings.instructor: Professor TSANG Ling Ming

courses.description: Students will be introduced to the theory and principle of common molecular techniques in marine biology and ecology. Topics will include, but not limited to: species identification through DNA barcoding, biodiversity assessment using environmental DNA and food web analyses using DNA metabarcoding. The second part of the course will workshop focusing on discussing the application of these techniques to specific student projects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biology or MPhil-PhD Environmental Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

- explain the principle and practice of the common techniques employed in contemporary marine biological and ecological research

- select and apply appropriate techniques to their own research project
courses.course_syllabus:
- Design of research in marine ecological studies

- Stable isotope analysis vs DNA metabarcoding in food web analyses

- eDNA metabarcoding analyses for biodiversity assessment

- Advantages and limitations on the techniques
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation

Discussion with students
courses.required_readings: Relevant journal articles and other reading materials to be distributed by instructors.

courses.description: Students will survey the literature in their chosen field of research and present a critical seminar on the topic. Presentation topics can also be chosen from an area that is relevant to their research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Environmental Science; or MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.learning_outcomes:
After finishing the course, students should be able to
(1) acquire core knowledge in life sciences and in-depth knowledge in a particular field of life sciences for research.
(2) acquire life-long learning skills to be an independent researcher.
(3) acquire knowledge to plan research work.
(4) acquire generic skills such as analytical skills, communication skills and writing skills.
(5) acquire skills how to prepare manuscript for publication.

courses.subject: LSCI
courses.title: Thesis Research

meetings.instructor: Staff
Staff

courses.description: In this course, a student is required to meet regularly with his/her supervisor who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Environmental Science; or MPhil-PhD Food & Nutritional Sciences; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.learning_outcomes: Development of research skills, including field and/or laboratory studies and data analysis as related to the students' thesis research.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Identify a research topic

- Develop a research hypothesis

- Prepare a research proposal

- Develop research methodology and experimental design

- Conduct an original *research* with impact in a specific field or subject

- Analyze experimental results and make appropriate data interpretation

- Prepare a research dissertation/thesis and related manuscripts for publication
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Discussion with students

2. Self-reflection of teacher(s)

3. Feedback from alumni

4. Feedback from Visiting Committee and regular programme reviews
